facts.text: This appeal is by special leave from the order of the Calcutta High Court dated May 16, 1958

anchor.surface_text: Raghubar Dayal, J. This appeal, by special leave, is from the order of the Calcutta High Court dated May 16, 1958, summarily dismissing the appeal of the appellant from the order of the learned Single Judge of the High Court

facts.text: Calcutta High Court summarily dismissed the appeal of the appellant from the order of the learned Single Judge

anchor.surface_text: dated May 16, 1958, summarily dismissing the appeal of the appellant from the order of the learned Single Judge of the High Court convicting him on jury trial of offences under s. 120B read with s. 471

facts.text: Learned Single Judge of the High Court convicted appellant on jury trial of offences under s. 120B read with s. 471 IPC and two counts under s. 471 read with s. 466 IPC with respect to two documents

anchor.surface_text: convicting him on jury trial of offences under s. 120B read with s. 471, Indian Penal Code, and on two counts under s. 471 read with s. 466, Indian Penal Code, with respect to two documents.

facts.text: L. N. Kalyanam was tried at the same trial and convicted of offences under s. 120B read with s. 471 IPC, two counts under s. 466 IPC, and s. 109 read with s. 471 IPC, did not appeal

anchor.surface_text: L. N. Kalyanam, who was also tried at the same trial and convicted of the offences under s. 120B read with s. 471, Indian Penal Code, two counts under s. 466, Indian Penal Code, and of the offence under s. 109, read with S. 471, Indian Penal Code, did not appeal against his conviction.

facts.text: Appellant Purushottamdas Dalmia was one of the partners of the firm Laxminarayan Gourishankar with head office at Gaya and branch at Calcutta at 19, Sambhu Mallick Lane

anchor.surface_text: The brief facts of the prosecution case are that the appellant Purushottamdas Dalmia was one of the partners of the firm known as Laxminarayan Gourishankar which had its head office at Gaya and branch at Calcutta. The Calcutta branch was located at 19, Sambhu Mallick Lane.

facts.text: On April 26, 1952, appellant applied for a licence for importing rupees one crore worth of art silk yarn

anchor.surface_text: On April 26, 1952, the appellant applied for a licence for importing rupees one crore worth of art silk yarn.

facts.text: On May 2, 1952, Joint Chief Controller of Imports, Calcutta, issued provisional licence

anchor.surface_text: On May 2, 1952, the Joint Chief Controller of Imports, Calcutta, issued a provisional licence.

facts.text: Provisional licence was not confirmed within two months and appellant informed of refusal to confirm

anchor.surface_text: This provisional licence was not confirmed within two months. The appellant was duly informed of the refusal to confirm the licence.

facts.text: Appellant's appeal against refusal to confirm licence dismissed in September 1952

anchor.surface_text: The appellants appeal against the refusal to confirm the licence was dismissed in September 1952.

facts.text: Provisional licences returned to appellant; letter dated September 26, 1952 from Joint Chief Controller communicating dismissal and return

anchor.surface_text: The provisional licences issued were returned to the appellant. The letter communicating the dismissal of the appeal and the return of the licence was issued from the office of the Joint Chief Controller of Imports on September 26, 1952.

facts.text: Letter dated September 29, 1952 from Chief Controller of Imports, New Delhi informed appellant instructions issued for re-consideration

anchor.surface_text: The letter dated September 29, 1952, from the office of the Chief Controller of Imports, New Delhi, informed the appellant with reference to the letter dated September 4, 1952, that instructions had been issued to the Joint Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, Calcutta, for re-consideration of such cases

facts.text: Appellant did not contact Joint Chief Controller based on September 29 letter; instead applied on October 7, 1952 for return of correspondence, returned October 9, 1952

anchor.surface_text: The appellant rightly, did not appear to take this letter to mean that the order of rejection of his appeal was still under further consideration. He did not take any steps to contact the Joint Chief Controller of Imports and Exports on the basis of this letter. Instead, he applied on October 7, 1952, for the return of correspondence. That correspondence was returned to him on October 9, 1952.

facts.text: On March 31, 1953, appellant wrote to Chief Controller of Imports, New Delhi expressing grievance

anchor.surface_text: Nothing happened up to March 31, 1953, on which date the appellant wrote to the Chief Controller of Imports, New Delhi, a long letter expressing his grievance at the action of the Joint Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, Calcutta, and requesting for a sympathetic decision.

facts.text: Chief Controller by letter dated April 20, 1953 informed appellant order could not be revised; letter had wrong number 16 instead of 19

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, by his letter dated April 20, 1953, informed the appellant that the order of the Joint Chief Controller of Imports and Exports could not be revised for the reasons mentioned in that letter. This letter gave the wrong number of the appellants firm. It mentioned its number as 16 instead of the correct number 19.

facts.text: Appellant states he did not receive April 20, 1953 letter

anchor.surface_text: The appellant states that he did not receive this letter.

facts.text: In August 1953, appellant met Kalyanam at Calcutta; Kalyanam said he could get licence validated through Rajan at Delhi

anchor.surface_text: In August 1953, the appellant met Kalyanam at Calcutta. Kalyanam told the appellant that he could get the licence validated through the good offices of one of his acquaintances, Rajan by name, at Delhi.

facts.text: In August 1953, appellant and Kalyanam went to Delhi, visited Rajan, appellant gave file containing licences to Kalyanam who gave to Rajan

anchor.surface_text: Both these persons came to Delhi in August, 1953, and visited Rajan. The appellant made over the file containing the licences to Kalyanam who in his turn made over the same to Rajan.

facts.text: Two or three days later, Kalyanam returned licences containing forged endorsements to appellant: confirmation purported July 2, 1952; re-validation April 25, 1953

anchor.surface_text: Two or three days later Kalyanam returned the licences containing the alleged forged endorsements to the appellant. The forged endorsements related to the confirmation of the licence and its re-validation till May 2, 1954. The confirmation endorsement was purported to be dated July 2, 1952, and the re-validating one purported to be dated April 25, 1953.

facts.text: Orders placed on basis of re-validated licence; goods arrived, attempt to clear at Madras; clearing office suspected endorsements, confirmed forgery, matter to Police

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, orders were placed on the basis of the re-validated licence and when the goods arrived attempt was made to clear them at Madras. The clearing office at Madras suspected the genuineness of the confirmation and re-validating endorsements and finding the suspicion confirmed, made over the matter to the Police.

facts.text: As result of investigation, appellant and Kalyanam committed to High Court for trial; eight charges framed

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the investigation and preliminary enquiry, the appellant and Kalyanam were committed to the High Court for trial. Eight charges were framed.

facts.text: Jury returned verdict of not guilty on charges 3,6 and conspiracy under 120B r/w 466; guilty on conspiracy 120B r/w 471 and charges 4,7 against appellant

anchor.surface_text: The jury returned a verdict of not guilty with respect to charges Nos. 3 and 6 and also with respect to the charge of conspiracy under s. 120B read with s. 466, Indian Penal Code. The jury returned a verdict of guilty against the appellant on the charge of conspiracy under s. 120B read with s. 471, Indian Penal Code and the other charges Nos. 4 and 7.

facts.text: It is not disputed that forgeries were committed in the two documents Exts. 5 and 6

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed, and cannot be disputed, that forgeries were committed in the two documents Exts. 5 and 6.

facts.text: Offences of using forged documents committed at Madras; appellant contended Calcutta courts no jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: The offences of using the forged documents as genuine were committed at Madras and therefore the Courts at Calcutta had no jurisdiction to try these offences under s. 471 read with s. 466, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court had jurisdiction to try conspiracy under s.120B IPC not disputed

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction of the Calcutta High Court to try an offence of criminal conspiracy under s. 120B, Indian Penal Code, is not disputed.

facts.text: Court holds Calcutta Court had jurisdiction to try offences under s.471 r/w 466 even though committed at Madras

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the Calcutta Court had jurisdiction to try the appellant of the offences under s. 471 read with s. 466, Indian Penal Code, even though those offences, in pursuance of the conspiracy, were committed at Madras.

issues.text: Whether the Court having jurisdiction to try the offence of conspiracy can try an offence constituted by such overt acts which are committed beyond its jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: in view of s. 177 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, that the Court having jurisdiction to try the offence of conspiracy cannot try an offence constituted by such overt acts which are committed beyond its jurisdiction and reliance is placed on the decision in Jiban Banerjee v. State

issues.text: Whether a charge of alternative conspiracies is permissible or whether the charge of conspiracy to commit offences under sections 466 or 471 IPC in the alternative is valid

anchor.surface_text: Such a charge is justified by the provisions of s. 236 of the Code. We are therefore of the opinion that the charge of conspiracy does not suffer from any illegality.

issues.text: Whether the trial judge misdirected the jury on the knowledge of forgery from ante-dating, validity of ante-dated endorsement as forgery, receipt of the April 20, 1953 letter, and expression of strong opinions affecting the jury

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge misdirected the jury in putting certain matters before it in the form he had done. The chief criticisms in this connection were that (a) the accused must have known from the ante-dating of the confirmation endorsement that the re-validation of the licence was a forgery (b) even if the proper officer of the Department had signed the re-validation, it would still be a forgery when it was ante-dated (c) the letter of the Chief Controller of Imports and Exports dated April 20, 1953, though wrongly addressed, must have reached the appellant (d) the learned Judge expressed his opinions strongly and this could have unduly affected the mind of the jury

holdings.text: The Calcutta Court had jurisdiction to try the appellant of the offences under s. 471 read with s. 466, Indian Penal Code, even though those offences, in pursuance of the conspiracy, were committed at Madras.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the Calcutta Court had jurisdiction to try the appellant of the offences under s. 471 read with s. 466, Indian Penal Code, even though those offences, in pursuance of the conspiracy, were committed at Madras.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.177 CrPC is ordinary rule, not peremptory; ss.235 & 239 permit joint trial of offences in same transaction irrespective of territorial jurisdiction; policy favors avoiding duplicate trials & inconsistent verdicts; s.531 cures territorial irregularities absent failure of justice; Jiban Banerjee wrongly decided.

holdings.text: The charge of conspiracy does not suffer from any illegality.

anchor.surface_text: Such a charge is justified by the provisions of s. 236 of the Code. We are therefore of the opinion that the charge of conspiracy does not suffer from any illegality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge is one conspiracy with alternative objects (forgery under s.466 or use as genuine under s.471); justified by s.236 CrPC for uncertain nature of offence.

holdings.text: The charge to the jury does not suffer from any misdirection.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Judge correctly stated law on ante-dated endorsements as forgery & knowledge therefrom; opinions not binding on jury who decide facts independently; letter likely received despite minor address error; no undue influence.

holdings.text: Jiban Banerjee v. State has not been rightly decided.

anchor.surface_text: We have considered it carefully and are of opinion that it has not been rightly decided.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Desirability of joint trial of conspiracy & overt acts outweighs strict territorial limits; leads to duplication of evidence & risk of inconsistent verdicts.

holdings.text: An ante-dated endorsement, even by proper officer, constitutes forgery as a false document.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ante-dated document is false document under IPC forgery provisions.

precedents.case_name: Assistant Sessions Judge North Arcot v Ramaswami Asari
precedents.cited_proposition: Scheme of Chapter XV to enlarge ambit of trial sites and minimise inconvenience from technical pleas on territorial jurisdiction
precedents.cited_holding: The scheme of Chapter XV, sub-chapter  A  in which sections 177 to 189 appear, seems to me to be intended to enlarge as much as possible the ambit of the sites in which the trial of an offence might be held and to minimise as much as possible the inconvenience which would be cause to the prosecution, by the success of a technical plea that the offence was number companymitted within the local limits of the jurisdiction of the trying Court.

precedents.cited_holding: I am doubtful about the matter, I must say but giving the best companysideration I can to it, and with this expression of opinion of the Calcutta High Court, I am inclined to think that jurisdiction, being the foundation of the charge, is to be imported or understood as present in all the subsequent procedure set out in the Code and if that is so, it clearly must govern s. 239.

precedents.cited_proposition: Under s.239(d), offences committed in course of same transaction including conspiracy and overt acts in pursuance thereof can be tried together without limit on number
precedents.cited_holding: Nor is there any limit of number of offences specified in s. 239 d . The one and only limitation there is that the accusation should be of offences companymitted in the companyrse of the same transaction. Whatever scope of companynotation may be included in the words the same transaction, it is enough for the present case to say that if several persons companyspire to companymit offences, and companymit overt acts in pursuance of the companyspiracy  a circumstance which makes the act of one the act of each and all the companyspirators , these acts are companymitted in the companyrse of the same transaction, which embraces the companyspiracy and the acts done under it.
